DOC.HEAD: Political Risk for Bush Grows as Panama Operation Drags On
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's order to send American troops into combat in Panama, initially greeted with broad support in Congress, could backfire politically if casualties continue to mount and the United States becomes bogged down there. The dangers are clear. How high will the U.S. death toll climb? Will deposed ruler Manuel Noriega continue to evade U.S. forces that were once confident of capturing him? Will the fragile government of Guillermo Endara, installed by the United States but dependent on U.S. power for his authority, take hold? How long before U.S. forces can be withdrawn? And, what about American hostages? The hazards were demonstrated after Bush declared the situation ``pretty well wrapped up'' Thursday and military officers described it as a mopping-up operation. On Friday, Noriega loyalists attacked the headquarters of U.S. military forces and Gen. Maxwell R. Thurman, commander in chief of the U.S. Southern Command, said U.S. forces were still fighting ``a real war.'' The stubborn resistance prompted the Pentagon to order an additional 2,000 soldiers into Panama, backing up a force of nearly 24,000 already there. For now, the political support for Bush's action seems to be holding. ``We're in the adrenalin-pumping stage, the first rally-around-the-flag moments,'' said Stephen Hess, a Brookings Institution senior fellow and specialist on the presidency. ``There hasn't been any major downside but you can start seeing it coming.'' University of Virginia political scientist Larry Sabato said, ``The first reaction is to support the president but then the doubts start seeping in and the worries and the questions.'' William Schneider, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and a political analyst, said, ``The only question is whether it's going to work and whether it's going to work quickly. ``Americans don't like to make an open-ended commitment anywhere, particularly where it involves the loss of American lives,'' Schneider said. ``Americans believe we should win or get out. In Grenada, we won. In Lebanon, we got out.'' Bush said U.S. forces will chase Noriega ``as long as it takes.'' He said the deployment of combat troops in Panama is open-ended as the chase continues and U.S. forces try to restore some semblance of order to the country. Already, there are demands in Congress for American troops to be brought home quickly. But Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said some U.S. forces might have to remain as police until ``Christmas Eve a year from now.'' A military operation initially described as a three- to four-day mission now stretches into the indefinite future. White House officials insist, however, that the operation is following the script they envisioned. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, briefed Bush last Sunday on the risks and ``laid it out almost exactly as it materialized.'' He said Powell accurately predicted Noriega would not be captured immediately, that hostages might be taken and that there would be a protracted period before U.S. forces would wrest control of Panama City from Noriega's Panamanian Defense Forces and his so-called Dignity Battalions. Fitzwater also said the U.S. death count will not be large. ``It doesn't seem likely there would be large-scale engagements with large amounts of casualties,'' he said. Before the invasion, U.S. intelligence sources had reported that Noriega was drinking heavily and that his mental state had deteriorated. ``General Noriega ... has been acting irrationally, beyond his normal conduct,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Nunn said administration officials, in private briefings for Congress, ``made a very strong case'' for the invasion. However, there are fears that public opinion may turn against Bush if the operation drags on. Hess said Bush ``probably doesn't have more than a month of real grace. The trick is always that it doesn't become our war.'' Schneider, the AEI analyst, said, ``The best outcome for the Bush administration would be for this guy to be dead, not make trouble for anybody.'' But the Panamanian leader remains at large, while U.S. casualties mount. And even if he is captured, the onetime CIA operative could make some embarrassing demands for secret documents if brought to trial in the United States. ``He knows where a lot of skeletons are buried in Central America and some of them may be very close to Bush's office,'' Schneider said, noting contacts between Bush's vice presidential staff and key figures in the Iran-Contra affair. ``If Noriega's caught,'' Schneider said, ``that's not the end of the matter.''
Terence Hunt is chief White House correspondent for The Associated Press.
